hedline.hl1: The best, the brightest and 'The Bell Curve.'

block.p: Malcolm W. Browne cites me as saying that American I.Q.'s have fallen about five points since 1900. If I said that, I was wrong. Average American I.Q.'s have, if anything, remained stable, if not grown, over that period. He goes on to cite the decline in S.A.T. scores between 1962 and 1990. But such a change cannot be hereditary. Hereditary changes occur across generations; the period 1962-90 is within a single generation. DANIEL R. VINING JR. Philadelphia
